awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Designing, Implementing, and Evaluating Application Software for Meaningful Smartphone Use
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to develop formative theory that identifies software interface design patterns that promote compulsive smartphone usage habits and to invent alternative patterns that promote meaningful usage habits. Americans across diverse communities and all socioeconomic strata report engaging with their smartphones out of habit and in compulsive ways. Though smartphone use in general provides enormous value and quality-of-life enhancements to users, software designs that promote compulsive, habit-forming patterns of engagement leave users feeling frustrated with their own behavior and struggling to make changes. Historically, the scientific literature has examined these phenomena using monolithic constructs like "problematic Internet use" and "smartphone addiction," and design research has innovated in this space by creating stand-alone mechanisms that support users in self-policing their use of technology, such as lock-out tools and system-wide timers. This project shifts the design focus to the internal workings of the app itself and redesigns the existing experience to be less-habit forming, rather than attempting to combat its habit-forming nature through monitoring tools.

This research will use YouTube and Twitter, two of the most popular apps among American smartphone users, as testbeds for redesign. The first phase of this project will conduct a series of user-centered design activities with participants who identify as routine users of these popular media to understand what they value in their usage experiences, what they wish they could change, and how their behaviors relate to components of the interface. Using existing third-party application programming interfaces provided by the two platforms, the research will then redesign and implement a new version of the client application software for each technology. Finally, a four-week deployment study with twenty-five users of each technology will compare two weeks of baseline usage against two weeks of usage with the redesigned version of the target app. During both the baseline and intervention periods, log data of usage patterns will be collected (including frequency of use, duration of use, context of use, and engagement with various app features), as well as experience sampling method data probing users' satisfaction with their own behaviors. Exit interviews and a larger survey with participants will be conducted following the deployment to understand their experiences with redesigned YouTube and Twitter clients. At the conclusion of the study, these redesigned apps will be made available to the broader public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this work, we examined how users feel about their current use of YouTube and Twitter and the design patterns that lead them to feel a lack of control over how they spend their time. We found that many users of both platforms struggle to manage their use of each of these apps and point to specific designs as contributing factors, such as autoplay on YouTube, the disorganized content of their Twitter feed, and recommendations to view additional content.

 

We designed several alternative versions of YouTube and Twitter that attempt to systematically influence the app’s effect on users’ ability to manage their attention, and we tested these by asking people to use different versions of the app over several weeks in place of the time they would otherwise spend with Twitter or YouTube.

 

We found that the ways designers support users in managing their attention can either be internal changes to the main user scenarios of the app, or they can be external changes that add in new forms of outside support, like a tool to track usage or lock the user out of the app. We found that these external supports could be helpful, but these forms of support were less effective than internal changes, and they annoyed users--at times even leaving them feeling like they had less control than ever over their experience. In contrast, internal changes left users feeling more satisfied with how they spent their time and a greater sense of agency. This suggests that changing the design of an app that encourages compulsive usage habits is likely to be more effective than adding outside screen time tools to police this usage.

 

We also found that designs that increased users’ sense of control did not always change the amount of time they spent with the app, and specifically, did not necessarily lead them to reduce their usage. Instead, users said that they spent their time with the app more effectively and felt more satisfied with their choice to use it. This suggests that designing to support people in using technology intentionally is not necessarily at odds with business objectives. It also suggests that measuring "screen time" is not helpful for understanding digital wellbeing.

 

We found that some design patterns appear to support intentional usage, and we provide proof-of-concept examples showing these design patterns in working apps. For example, displaying a message to tell a user “You’re All Caught Up,” providing a toggle to turn recommendations on and off at will, and dividing up endless streams of content into organized compartments all improved users’ ability to stay focused on their reasons for using the app. We found that sometimes users enjoy being carried along in the recommendations and interesting content served up by an app, and that a toggle that allows them to switch between the app supporting them in following their focused intention and the app helping them to explore new things can meet two important needs and provide the greatest sense of control.

 

Finally, we found that when users mindlessly browse platforms, they slip into a state known as “normative dissociation,” a natural process of mind-wandering that suppresses self-control. This offers a new, and potentially more useful, way of understanding people's experiences overusing technology than  thinking of them as “technology addiction.” This also suggests designers have a responsibility to support users in spending their time and attention the way they want to, because once in a dissociative state, people cannot simply exit it by exerting self-control.

 

In conducting this work, we created two new, fully functional apps for Android phones. We have discussed these findings with members of industry and academia interested in designing digital experiences that support users’ wellbeing.
